blog.name: princessmissandei
blog.title: Night Wolf
blog.description: Marie | Slytherin | Writer About and Before You Follow Multi-fandom blog with an emphasis on ASOIAF and various period dramas. Very fond of canon Starks, Targaryens, Durrandons and Baratheons. Reylos do not engage.

tags: i cant wait for them to lie and say they dont do this only for their blogs to be full of it
summary: In light of the latest wank, I have a genuine question for Sansa stans: why do so many of you heavily rely on hatred toward...
body:
In light of the latest wank, I have a genuine question for Sansa stans: why do so many of you heavily rely on hatred toward other female characters in order to defend or prop up Sansa? Why can’t she be discussed with her own merits rather than with negativity toward other women?

This has literally been going on for YEARS. For the longest time, Arya has been the main target for this fandom with post dedicated to hating multiple women at once with some of the most disgusting misogyny I’ve ever seen speckled here and there. Now, Dany is sharing the Sansa Stans Most Hated Character spot alongside Arya. I understand that men have pit women against each other for millennia by creating a societal structure where only some can appear to succeed at the expense of others, which has resulted in women almost instinctively targeting each other even when it doesn’t make any sense to do so. But we are moving into the year 2019. No one should so backward that they’re still relying on those archaic practices.

So … why? Why are you Sansa stans like this?

So … why? Why are you Sansa stans like this?

summary: I know that Ayra is a bad ass, and Dany is a bad ass, and now y’all want to add Sansa to that list, but let me tell y’all...
body: I know that Ayra is a bad ass, and Dany is a bad ass, and now y’all want to add Sansa to that list, but let me tell y’all something. Y’all wanted to call her weak and annoying, nu huh. She was a bad ass fighter from the start. Just because she can’t fight like her sister, or command armies like Dany, doesn’t mean shit. If you had put Ayra or Dany in Sansa’s position, they’d be dead within the week. She survived Joffrey and Cersi, by keeping her head in all that chaos and torture. But noooo. That doesn’t count. She wasn’t even paid attention to until she fed a rapist to his own dogs, and ended little finger. Don’t get me wrong, those were amazing things, and I screamed for her, but y’all….y’all slept on Sansa Stark. She should have been considered a bad ass at “maybe he’ll give me yours.” Like. Gurl got some big wolf balls, bye.

body:

summary: Everyone knows about the scene where Lady is killed and everyone knows about the scene where Sansa runs to Cersei but few people...
body:
Everyone knows about the scene where Lady is killed and everyone knows about the scene where Sansa runs to Cersei but few people bridge the gap between the two. The only conclusion people seem to come up with is that Sansa really, really likes the Lannister. The real conclusion is Sansa felt betrayed by her father and is lashing out.

Sansa doesn’t break rules. She is a good girl in her words. She does what is expected of her very well to the point that her parents rarely worry or wonder about her. The first instances of Sansa behaving less than perfectly were her feeding Lady under the table. It’s clear that Sansa spends a lot of time with her direwolf. Lady is well trained, clean and is often with Sansa. At this point, this is the extent of Sansa’s pre teen rebellion, that she sometimes feeds her pet in an inappropriate setting. Then Lady is killed. Many people have already analysed the scene and why Sansa chose not to pick a side so I won’t bother. The problem is that to many people this issue ends here and everything Sansa does afterwards is just Sansa being an asshole. It’s clearly not. The Trident incident changed Sansa in many ways.

The change in Sansa’s behaviour starts small:

The kitchen yielded no lemon cakes, but they did find half of a cold strawberry pie, and that was almost as good. They ate it on the tower steps, giggling and gossiping and sharing secrets, and Sansa went to bed that night feeling almost as wicked as Arya. 

Taking food from the kitchen likely without permission. There’s also this:

She turned to Septa Mordane, who was eating porridge with a wooden spoon. “Septa, will Lord Beric spike Ser Gregor’s head on his own gate or bring it back here for the king?” She and Jeyne Poole had been arguing over that last night.

The septa was horror-struck. “A lady does not discuss such things over her porridge. Where are your courtesies, Sansa? I swear, of late you’ve been near as bad as your sister.”

Discussing the many ways one can handle the body of a criminal is not standard Sansa behaviour at all. Can you imagine the Sansa we meet in Winterfell talking about this? I’m not saying it’s not entirely possible, I’m saying the violence she witnessed as well as Lady dying has given Sansa a cavalier look at death for a while. In fact the only time we see her being praised by the septa while in King’s Landing is when she’s stone faced watching someone die. Not only that, Sansa’s constantly fighting with Arya. The impression we get of them in Winterfell is Arya being scolded for not acting like Sansa and Jeyne (and sometimes Sansa and Theon) called Arya ‘Horseface’ but most importantly that Arya ran off to play other children and Jon. The only time we see them together is during their lessons. After Lady dies, they argue a lot.

“Liar,” Arya said. Her hand clenched the blood orange so hard that red juice oozed between her fingers.

“Go ahead, call me all the names you want,” Sansa said airily. “You won’t dare when I’m married to Joffrey. You’ll have to bow to me and call me Your Grace.”

.

Finally she found her voice. “What about my dress?”

“Maybe … I could wash it,” Arya said doubtfully.

“Washing won’t do any good,” Sansa said. “Not if you scrubbed all day and all night. The silk is ruined.”

“Then I’ll … make you a new one,” Arya said.

Sansa threw back her head in disdain. “You? You couldn’t sew a dress fit to clean the pigsties.”

.

Sansa’s eyes had grown wide as the plates. “A tourney,” she breathed. She was seated between Septa Mordane and Jeyne Poole, as far from Arya as she could get without drawing a reproach from Father.

.

“I don’t care about their stupid tourney,” Arya said. She knew Prince Joffrey would be there, and she hated Prince Joffrey.

Sansa lifted her head. “It will be a splendid event. You shan’t be wanted.”

Anger flashed across Father’s face. “Enough, Sansa. More of that and you will change my mind. I am weary unto death of this endless war you two are fighting. You are sisters. I expect you to behave like sisters, is that understood?”

While the fighting between them is noticed, no one is really seeing the changes in Sansa’s behaviour, her need to be grown up is more intense now, her showing up at places without permission (going to court while the Riverlands peasants talk about the horrible things they have suffered), etc. unless she’s exploding in anger

“You have juice on your face, Your Grace,” Arya said.

It was running down her nose and stinging her eyes. Sansa wiped it away with a napkin. When she saw what the fruit in her lap had done to her beautiful ivory silk dress, she shrieked again. “You’re horrible,” she screamed at her sister. “They should have killed you instead of Lady!”

Septa Mordane came lurching to her feet. “Your lord father will hear of this! Go to your chambers, at once. At once!”

.

Sansa felt tears in her eyes. “He is not! He’s not the least bit like that old drunken king,” she screamed at her sister, forgetting herself in her grief.

.

“It won’t be so bad, Sansa,” Arya said. “We’re going to sail on a galley. It will be an adventure, and then we’ll be with Bran and Robb again, and Old Nan and Hodor and the rest.” She touched her on the arm.

“Hodor!” Sansa yelled. “You ought to marry Hodor, you’re just like him, stupid and hairy and ugly!” She wrenched away from her sister’s hand, stormed into her bedchamber, and barred the door behind her.

Another element people rarely discuss (unless it’s to pretend that’s another sign of why Arya is better than her) is that Sansa felt jealous of Ned and Arya’s relationship. It always seemed like Arya could no wrong and yet Sansa is the one being punished.

None of which stopped Arya, of course. One day she came back grinning her horsey grin, her hair all tangled and her clothes covered in mud, clutching a raggedy bunch of purple and green flowers for Father. Sansa kept hoping he would tell Arya to behave herself and act like the highborn lady she was supposed to be, but he never did, he only hugged her and thanked her for the flowers. That just made her worse.

.

“You’re not supposed to leave the column,” Sansa reminded her. “Father said so.”

Arya shrugged. “I didn’t go far. Anyway, Nymeria was with me the whole time. I don’t always go off, either. Sometimes it’s fun just to ride along with the wagons and talk to people.”

Ned rarely interacted with Sansa during the first book unless he was telling her she couldn’t go somewhere or scolding her in the aftermath of yet another fight or the ‘trial’ by the Trident or breaking her betrothal to Joffrey. Every interaction is either tense or it involves Sansa losing something important. In contrast Ned takes the time to explain things to Arya and takes into account her feelings and wishes. Ned gets Arya a dancing master and decides when they leave King’s Landing to keep employing the man. Contrast this to Sansa’s situation:

Sansa cried as Septa Mordane marched them down the steps. They were going to take it all away; the tournaments and the court and her prince, everything, they were going to send her back to the bleak grey walls of Winterfell and lock her up forever. Her life was over before it had begun.

Sansa was really happy to leave the North and experience the rest of the world. Without explanation beyond Joffrey’s personal failings that Ned didn’t mention until this point. It would seem supremely unfair to Sansa and it wouldn’t be the first time. When Robert asked for Lady to be killed and Ned did it, Sansa felt betrayed. After all Robert was Ned’s friend, Ned could have fought against it especially since it was obvious to everyone what really happened but he didn’t. There’s no reference in either his chapters or Sansa’s if they even interacted after that, if Ned comforted Sansa, if he told her where Lady’s body was going. Nothing. This is why Sansa’s relationship with Arya is so bad.  Sansa could not be angry at her father so she turn her anger towards Arya instead because it was easier. Until she started seeing Ned as the problem.

Sansa going to Cersei had little to do with Joffrey though Sansa was swept up by the romance she fabricated. For all that Sansa says she loves Joffrey, she doesn’t think about him often and when she does there’s this desperation to view him as someone from a story rather than a real person. It reads more like infatuation than any real affection. Sansa’s anger and hurt at her father is more real and is the main motivation for her actions.

When she runs to Cersei, she tells herself it’s for Joffrey because it’s easier than admitting to herself that her father doesn’t love or care about her as much as he does his other children, specifically Arya.

reblog.comment:

Ned rarely interacted with Sansa during the first book unless he was telling her she couldn’t go somewhere or scolding her in the aftermath of yet another fight or the ‘trial’ by the Trident or breaking her betrothal to Joffrey. Every interaction is either tense or it involves Sansa losing something important. In contrast Ned takes the time to explain things to Arya and takes into account her feelings and wishes. Ned gets Arya a dancing master and decides when they leave King’s Landing to keep employing the man. Contrast this to Sansa’s situation:

Sansa cried as Septa Mordane marched them down the steps. They were going to take it all away; the tournaments and the court and her prince, everything, they were going to send her back to the bleak grey walls of Winterfell and lock her up forever. Her life was over before it had begun.

Sansa was really happy to leave the North and experience the rest of the world. Without explanation beyond Joffrey’s personal failings that Ned didn’t mention until this point. It would seem supremely unfair to Sansa and it wouldn’t be the first time. When Robert asked for Lady to be killed and Ned did it, Sansa felt betrayed. After all Robert was Ned’s friend, Ned could have fought against it especially since it was obvious to everyone what really happened but he didn’t. There’s no reference in either his chapters or Sansa’s if they even interacted after that, if Ned comforted Sansa, if he told her where Lady’s body was going. Nothing. This is why Sansa’s relationship with Arya is so bad.  Sansa could not be angry at her father so she turn her anger towards Arya instead because it was easier. Until she started seeing Ned as the problem.

Sansa going to Cersei had little to do with Joffrey though Sansa was swept up by the romance she fabricated. For all that Sansa says she loves Joffrey, she doesn’t think about him often and when she does there’s this desperation to view him as someone from a story rather than a real person. It reads more like infatuation than any real affection. Sansa’s anger and hurt at her father is more real and is the main motivation for her actions.

When she runs to Cersei, she tells herself it’s for Joffrey because it’s easier than admitting to herself that her father doesn’t love or care about her as much as he does his other children, specifically Arya.

trail.content_raw:
Everyone knows about the scene where Lady is killed and everyone knows about the scene where Sansa runs to Cersei but few people bridge the gap between the two. The only conclusion people seem to come up with is that Sansa really, really likes the Lannister. The real conclusion is Sansa felt betrayed by her father and is lashing out.

Sansa doesn’t break rules. She is a good girl in her words. She does what is expected of her very well to the point that her parents rarely worry or wonder about her. The first instances of Sansa behaving less than perfectly were her feeding Lady under the table. It’s clear that Sansa spends a lot of time with her direwolf. Lady is well trained, clean and is often with Sansa. At this point, this is the extent of Sansa’s pre teen rebellion, that she sometimes feeds her pet in an inappropriate setting. Then Lady is killed. Many people have already analysed the scene and why Sansa chose not to pick a side so I won’t bother. The problem is that to many people this issue ends here and everything Sansa does afterwards is just Sansa being an asshole. It’s clearly not. The Trident incident changed Sansa in many ways.

The change in Sansa’s behaviour starts small:

The kitchen yielded no lemon cakes, but they did find half of a cold strawberry pie, and that was almost as good. They ate it on the tower steps, giggling and gossiping and sharing secrets, and Sansa went to bed that night feeling almost as wicked as Arya. 

Taking food from the kitchen likely without permission. There’s also this:

She turned to Septa Mordane, who was eating porridge with a wooden spoon. “Septa, will Lord Beric spike Ser Gregor’s head on his own gate or bring it back here for the king?” She and Jeyne Poole had been arguing over that last night.

The septa was horror-struck. “A lady does not discuss such things over her porridge. Where are your courtesies, Sansa? I swear, of late you’ve been near as bad as your sister.”

Discussing the many ways one can handle the body of a criminal is not standard Sansa behaviour at all. Can you imagine the Sansa we meet in Winterfell talking about this? I’m not saying it’s not entirely possible, I’m saying the violence she witnessed as well as Lady dying has given Sansa a cavalier look at death for a while. In fact the only time we see her being praised by the septa while in King’s Landing is when she’s stone faced watching someone die. Not only that, Sansa’s constantly fighting with Arya. The impression we get of them in Winterfell is Arya being scolded for not acting like Sansa and Jeyne (and sometimes Sansa and Theon) called Arya ‘Horseface’ but most importantly that Arya ran off to play other children and Jon. The only time we see them together is during their lessons. After Lady dies, they argue a lot.

“Liar,” Arya said. Her hand clenched the blood orange so hard that red juice oozed between her fingers.

“Go ahead, call me all the names you want,” Sansa said airily. “You won’t dare when I’m married to Joffrey. You’ll have to bow to me and call me Your Grace.”

.

Finally she found her voice. “What about my dress?”

“Maybe … I could wash it,” Arya said doubtfully.

“Washing won’t do any good,” Sansa said. “Not if you scrubbed all day and all night. The silk is ruined.”

“Then I’ll … make you a new one,” Arya said.

Sansa threw back her head in disdain. “You? You couldn’t sew a dress fit to clean the pigsties.”

.

Sansa’s eyes had grown wide as the plates. “A tourney,” she breathed. She was seated between Septa Mordane and Jeyne Poole, as far from Arya as she could get without drawing a reproach from Father.

.

“I don’t care about their stupid tourney,” Arya said. She knew Prince Joffrey would be there, and she hated Prince Joffrey.

Sansa lifted her head. “It will be a splendid event. You shan’t be wanted.”

Anger flashed across Father’s face. “Enough, Sansa. More of that and you will change my mind. I am weary unto death of this endless war you two are fighting. You are sisters. I expect you to behave like sisters, is that understood?”

While the fighting between them is noticed, no one is really seeing the changes in Sansa’s behaviour, her need to be grown up is more intense now, her showing up at places without permission (going to court while the Riverlands peasants talk about the horrible things they have suffered), etc. unless she’s exploding in anger

“You have juice on your face, Your Grace,” Arya said.

It was running down her nose and stinging her eyes. Sansa wiped it away with a napkin. When she saw what the fruit in her lap had done to her beautiful ivory silk dress, she shrieked again. “You’re horrible,” she screamed at her sister. “They should have killed you instead of Lady!”

Septa Mordane came lurching to her feet. “Your lord father will hear of this! Go to your chambers, at once. At once!”

.

Sansa felt tears in her eyes. “He is not! He’s not the least bit like that old drunken king,” she screamed at her sister, forgetting herself in her grief.

.

“It won’t be so bad, Sansa,” Arya said. “We’re going to sail on a galley. It will be an adventure, and then we’ll be with Bran and Robb again, and Old Nan and Hodor and the rest.” She touched her on the arm.

“Hodor!” Sansa yelled. “You ought to marry Hodor, you’re just like him, stupid and hairy and ugly!” She wrenched away from her sister’s hand, stormed into her bedchamber, and barred the door behind her.

Another element people rarely discuss (unless it’s to pretend that’s another sign of why Arya is better than her) is that Sansa felt jealous of Ned and Arya’s relationship. It always seemed like Arya could no wrong and yet Sansa is the one being punished.

None of which stopped Arya, of course. One day she came back grinning her horsey grin, her hair all tangled and her clothes covered in mud, clutching a raggedy bunch of purple and green flowers for Father. Sansa kept hoping he would tell Arya to behave herself and act like the highborn lady she was supposed to be, but he never did, he only hugged her and thanked her for the flowers. That just made her worse.

.

“You’re not supposed to leave the column,” Sansa reminded her. “Father said so.”

Arya shrugged. “I didn’t go far. Anyway, Nymeria was with me the whole time. I don’t always go off, either. Sometimes it’s fun just to ride along with the wagons and talk to people.”

Ned rarely interacted with Sansa during the first book unless he was telling her she couldn’t go somewhere or scolding her in the aftermath of yet another fight or the ‘trial’ by the Trident or breaking her betrothal to Joffrey. Every interaction is either tense or it involves Sansa losing something important. In contrast Ned takes the time to explain things to Arya and takes into account her feelings and wishes. Ned gets Arya a dancing master and decides when they leave King’s Landing to keep employing the man. Contrast this to Sansa’s situation:

Sansa cried as Septa Mordane marched them down the steps. They were going to take it all away; the tournaments and the court and her prince, everything, they were going to send her back to the bleak grey walls of Winterfell and lock her up forever. Her life was over before it had begun.

Sansa was really happy to leave the North and experience the rest of the world. Without explanation beyond Joffrey’s personal failings that Ned didn’t mention until this point. It would seem supremely unfair to Sansa and it wouldn’t be the first time. When Robert asked for Lady to be killed and Ned did it, Sansa felt betrayed. After all Robert was Ned’s friend, Ned could have fought against it especially since it was obvious to everyone what really happened but he didn’t. There’s no reference in either his chapters or Sansa’s if they even interacted after that, if Ned comforted Sansa, if he told her where Lady’s body was going. Nothing. This is why Sansa’s relationship with Arya is so bad.  Sansa could not be angry at her father so she turn her anger towards Arya instead because it was easier. Until she started seeing Ned as the problem.

Sansa going to Cersei had little to do with Joffrey though Sansa was swept up by the romance she fabricated. For all that Sansa says she loves Joffrey, she doesn’t think about him often and when she does there’s this desperation to view him as someone from a story rather than a real person. It reads more like infatuation than any real affection. Sansa’s anger and hurt at her father is more real and is the main motivation for her actions.

When she runs to Cersei, she tells herself it’s for Joffrey because it’s easier than admitting to herself that her father doesn’t love or care about her as much as he does his other children, specifically Arya.

blog.name: clevercloudpoetry
blog.title: Gendrya is Canon!
blog.description: She/her. Way too many Fandoms and way too many OTPs. I like to think I'm funny. My blog is a mess but it's most of the things I like so... I sometimes make edits and write, not great at either of those things but trying to be better. Multifandom Blog.

summary:
Arya:	Did you tell anybody we’re engaged?
Gendry:	Yes, Arya, I have no self-control and I told everyone in Winterfell we’re...
body:
Arya:	Did you tell anybody we’re engaged?
Gendry:	Yes, Arya, I have no self-control and I told everyone in Winterfell we’re engaged.
Arya:	Okay, no need to be sarcastic.
Gendry:	No, seriously, I have no self-control and I told everyone in Winterfell we’re engaged.

summary: Jon (to Dany): Would you like to stay for dinner? Sansa, Arya and Bran(while hiding behind the curtains): Would you like to stay...
body:
Jon (to Dany): Would you like to stay for dinner?
Sansa, Arya and Bran(while hiding behind the curtains): Would you like to stay forever???

blog.title: Night Wolf
blog.description: Marie | Slytherin | Writer About and Before You Follow Multi-fandom blog with an emphasis on ASOIAF and various period dramas. Very fond of canon Starks, Targaryens, Durrandons and Baratheons. Reylos do not engage.

tags: i dont think it will happen on the show if only bc of the very little time available
just pointing out how happy Sansa was while gushing about Jons love for Arya
summary: "What do you know of my heart, priestess? What do you know of my sister?"
body:
“What do you know of my heart, priestess? What do you know of my sister?”

– Jon equating Arya with his heart, ADWD

Whether one ships Jon/Arya romantically, adores their dynamic as the closest of siblings, or has no feeling about them at all, there should be no denying that in-universe Jon considers his heart and Arya Stark to be one and the same. Not only does he outright say exactly that, his heart is often mentioned in relation to her throughout ADWD. Even in the showverse Sansa mentions how much more Jon loves Arya than he could ever love her by bringing up Jon’s heart. In fact, if Jonrya happened on the show, Sansa would clearly ship it.

Not only does he outright say exactly that, his heart is often mentioned in relation to her throughout ADWD. Even in the showverse Sansa mentions how much more Jon loves Arya than he could ever love her by bringing up Jon’s heart. In fact, if Jonrya happened on the show, Sansa would clearly ship it.
